channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2016 The New York Times Company

item.title: Throwing Stones and Slaughtering Sheep at the Hajj
item.media:description: Outside a slaughterhouse on the outskirts of Mecca, men hang around looking to work for tips, paid in cash or in chunks of meat.
item.description: Diaa Hadid, a Times correspondent making the Muslim pilgrimage to Mecca, picked up tips on how to practice some of the rites and rituals of the hajj.
item.dc:creator: DIAA HADID

item.title: Scaling Up a Drug Trade, Straight Through ISIS Turf
item.media:description: A jute suitcase containing 100 blocks of hashish in the office of the Guardia di Finanza, the Italian financial police force, in Palermo, Italy. The blocks were among 13 tons of hashish seized from the cargo ship Munzur in December.
item.media:credit: Gianni Cipriano for The New York Times
item.description: Hashish from Morocco was once smuggled to Europe a speedboat at a time. But the trafficking has escalated to huge cargo ships, on a route including a chaotic stretch of Libya.
item.dc:creator: RUKMINI CALLIMACHI and LORENZO TONDO
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Details of Syria Pact Widen Rift Between John Kerry and Pentagon
item.media:description: Secretary of State John Kerry, left, and Foreign Minister Sergey V. Lavrov of Russia this month in Geneva.
item.description: Defense Secretary Ashton Carter opposed the plan for U.S. and Russian military collaboration against ISIS, which Secretary of State John Kerry supports.
item.dc:creator: HELENE COOPER and DAVID E. SANGER
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: The View From Syria as a Cease-Fire Takes Effect
item.media:description: Even the less severe cases Dr. Omar Abu Mariam treats can be heart-rending, like Khaled, 8 months old, whose skull was fractured in a missile strike. Hours after the cease-fire was announced on Friday, doctors did not know where his mother was or “if she made it.”
item.description: Syrians celebrated the Eid holiday, and shared in skepticism of the truce: “Here, people can’t believe anything. But they are always waiting for peace.”
item.dc:creator: ANNE BARNARD and HWAIDA SAAD

item.title: In Expanding Russian Influence, Faith Combines With Firepower
item.media:description: A service for Russians killed in the Bastille Day terrorist attack at St. Nicholas Orthodox Cathedral in Nice, France.
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.description: The Russian Orthodox Church helps spread President Vladimir V. Putin’s gospel of illiberal democracy and traditional values, pushing into resolutely secular members of Europe like France.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW HIGGINS

item.title: British Lawmakers Condemn 2011 Intervention in Libya
item.media:description: A rebel fighter prepared to tow away a government truck mounted with a machine gun that was hit by a NATO airstrike near Brega, Libya, in April 2011.
item.description: A parliamentary committee said the former prime minister, David Cameron, “was ultimately responsible for the failure to develop a coherent Libya strategy.”
item.dc:creator: STEPHEN CASTLE

item.title: U.N. Chief Says North Korea Has Spawned Unprecedented Tension
item.description: Secretary General Ban Ki-moon urged the Security Council to take “urgent actions” in a news conference before his last annual General Assembly session as the United Nations leader.
item.dc:creator: SOMINI SENGUPTA

item.title: Obama Pledges to Lift All Sanctions Against Myanmar
item.media:description: Ms. Aung San Suu Kyi arrived at the White House on Wednesday.
item.description: President Obama, who met on Wednesday with Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, Myanmar’s leader, sought to reward the country for its efforts to establish a more democratic government.
item.dc:creator: JULIE HIRSCHFELD DAVIS

item.title: Abroad in America: Fearful and Flummoxed: Watching the Presidential Race From Abroad
item.media:description: Donald J. Trump made at a campaign stop Boulevard Diner in Dundalk, Md., on Monday.
item.description: Foreigners feel invested in the campaign’s outcome and raise questions about American law, during the election and beyond.
item.dc:creator: DECLAN WALSH

item.title: ‘Lula,’ Brazil’s Ex-President, Is Charged With Corruption
item.description: Prosecutors say that Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva and his wife illegally benefited from about $750,000 in work at a beachfront apartment paid for by a company seeking public contracts.
item.dc:creator: SIMON ROMERO

item.title: Muslim Teenager Proposes Emoji of Woman Wearing a Head Scarf
item.media:description: Potential emojis depicting headwear worn by Muslims.
item.description: A 15-year-old high school student in Berlin is proposing an emoji with a head scarf, or hijab, to represent the millions of Muslim women who wear one.
item.dc:creator: MELISSA EDDY

item.title: Scottish Nurse Who Had Ebola Is Cleared of Misconduct
item.media:description: Pauline Cafferkey, second from left, in Edinburgh on Wednesday. She contracted Ebola in Sierra Leone in 2014 and was accused of concealing her high temperature from health officials.
item.description: The nurse, Pauline Cafferkey, contracted Ebola in Sierra Leone in 2014 and had been accused of concealing her high temperature from health officials.
item.dc:creator: KIMIKO DE FREYTAS-TAMURA

item.title: After Years of War, Celebrities Find a Syrian Group to Back
item.media:description: Syrian Civil Defense volunteers, known as White Helmets, carried a survivor who was pulled from the debris of an airstrike in Aleppo on July 25.
item.description: Some in Hollywood are lobbying for the White Helmets to receive the Nobel Peace Prize.
item.dc:creator: LIAM STACK
item.category: White Helmets (Syrian Civil Defense Volunteer Group)

item.title: Memo From Britain: Theresa May, Britain’s Prime Minister, Plays the ‘Brexit’ Waiting Game
item.media:description: Despite pressure from Brussels to move quickly, Prime Minister Theresa May has said that Britain will not formally begin the two-year negotiation process to leave the European Union until the first quarter of 2017.
item.description: David Cameron’s successor has said little about how her country will withdraw from the European Union, and tough decisions loom.
item.dc:creator: STEVEN ERLANGER

item.title: The Winners and Losers as Europe Tries to Erase Borders for TV and Films
item.media:description: The BBC’s headquarters in London. Under new rules, so-called video-on-demand services from national broadcasters, like the BBC iPlayer, may become more readily available across the European Union.
item.description: The proposal aims to allow people across the bloc to stream shows online and give national broadcasters a Continent-size audience.
item.dc:creator: MARK SCOTT

item.title: Opposition Figure’s Rise Could Pave Way for Female Leaders in Japan
item.media:description: Renho Murata, center, at a debate in Tokyo with her political opponents Yuichiro Tamaki, left, and Seiji Maehara. Ms. Murata is vying to become the first woman to lead the Democratic Party.
item.description: The election of Renho Murata as head of the Democratic Party would be a step toward gender equality in a country that has lagged in promoting women.
item.dc:creator: MOTOKO RICH

item.title: China Expels 45 Lawmakers Over Election Fraud
item.media:description: Delegates to the National People’s Congress in Beijing in March. The nearly 3,000 members of the congress, which each March meets as a full body for less than two weeks, ratify laws and government programs.
item.description: Some of the officials, all from Liaoning Province, had bribed their way into the National People’s Congress by buying votes, state news media said.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL FORSYTHE

item.title: Refugees Pour Out of Turkey Once More as Deal With Europe Falters
item.media:description: A camp for migrants and asylum seekers on the Greek island of Chios this month. More than 1,000 refugees arrived in Greece last week, nearly double the number the previous week.
item.description: The number of refugees arriving in Greece nearly doubled last week, to more than 1,000. Many are realizing that an agreement to stanch the flow is not being enforced.
item.dc:creator: CEYLAN YEGINSU
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis

item.title: Australia’s Leader Calls for National Gay Marriage Vote
item.media:description: Supporters of same-sex marriage at a rally in Sydney, Australia, in June.
item.description: Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull asked Parliament to pass a bill that would set up a nonbinding plebiscite asking Australians to vote yes or no on the issue.
item.dc:creator: MICHELLE INNIS
item.category: Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships

item.title: Special Report: Democracy 2016: Overcoming Cruelty in Today’s Germany
item.media:description: Germans fleeing their homes in Berlin in August 1961, shortly before the construction of the wall. Chancellor Angela Merkel’s policy of welcoming thousands of migrants has baffled and angered many of her critics.
item.description: The Berlin Wall still holds lessons for the struggle against dictatorships.
item.dc:creator: ALISON SMALE

item.title: Justin Trudeau, Nearing a Year in Office, Tries to Recast Himself
item.media:description: Prime Minister Justin Trudeau on Parliament Hill in Ottawa in June.
item.description: Canada’s popular prime minister must soon demonstrate that he is not just a social media star but also a leader who will deliver on ambitious promises, analysts say.
item.dc:creator: IAN AUSTEN

item.title: After North Korea Flooding, Relief Agencies Help Tens of Thousands
item.media:description: The damage caused by heavy flooding of the Tumen River in North Hamgyong Province, North Korea.
item.media:credit: Murat Sahin/Unicef, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.description: North Korea reported hundreds of people dead or missing but has not publicly appealed for outside help, instead relying on internal mobilization.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Doctors: Israel's Peres Showing Improvement
item.description: Former Israeli President Shimon Peres' condition was showing slight improvements after he suffered a major stroke, with his physicians saying Wednesday that he had regained consciousness and squeezed his doctor's hand, while the nation rallied in prayer and support for the 93-year-old elder statesman and Nobel Peace Prize laureate.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Tip Leads to Vanished Arctic Exploration Ship After 168 Years
item.description: Scientists, researchers and the Canadian Navy and Coast Guard searched for the Terror, a British ship that vanished in 1848 while trying to map the Northwest Passage.
item.dc:creator: IAN AUSTEN

item.title: U.S. Finalizes Deal to Give Israel $38 Billion in Military Aid
item.media:description: President Obama and Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel in the Oval Office last year. The agreement represents a major American commitment to Israel’s security after years of fractious relations.
item.description: The agreement, which the allies plan to sign on Wednesday, represents a major American commitment to Israel’s security after years of fractious relations.
item.dc:creator: PETER BAKER and JULIE HIRSCHFELD DAVIS

item.title: Shimon Peres, Former Prime Minister of Israel, Suffers a Stroke
item.media:description: Shimon Peres, then president of Israel, visiting a school in Givatayim, east of Tel Aviv, in 2013.
item.media:credit: Uriel Sinai for The New York Times
item.description: Mr. Peres, 93, was sedated in a hospital and put on a respirator to breathe and was described as fighting for his life.
item.dc:creator: PETER BAKER

item.title: Britain’s New 5-Pound Note Is Chewable, Washable and Harder to Fake
item.media:description: Mark Carney, governor of the Bank of England, tests a new polymer 5-pound note by dipping it in a tray of food as he buys lunch at Whitecross Street Market in London.
item.description: The bill, printed for more than a century on cotton paper, now comes in polymer, a thin, flexible plastic film that makes it more resistant to criminals.
item.dc:creator: DAN BILEFSKY

item.title: For Myanmar’s Leader, More Power, but More Expectations, Too
item.media:description: President Obama with Ms. Aung San Suu Kyi at a summit meeting in Vientiane, Laos, last week.
item.media:credit: Ye Aung Thu/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.description: As Daw Aung San Suu Kyi nears her first trip to the U.S. as leader of Myanmar, officials are discussing whether to lift sanctions against the country.
item.dc:creator: STÉPHANIE GIRY

item.title: Top U.N. Rights Official Denounces Growing Efforts to Block His Monitoring
item.media:description: Zeid Ra’ad al-Hussein, the high commissioner for human rights at the United Nations, in Geneva, in August. He said on Tuesday that some member states often invoked what he described as spurious arguments that human rights inquiries violated national sovereignty.
item.description: The high commissioner for human rights, Zeid Ra’ad al-Hussein, said many nations have sought to evade scrutiny since the Human Rights Council was created a decade ago.
item.dc:creator: NICK CUMMING-BRUCE
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Letter From America: Donald Trump’s Admiration of Putin’s Ruthless Use of Power
item.description: Critics of the Republican presidential candidate say his kind words for the Russian leader reflect authoritarian and dangerous instincts.
item.dc:creator: JOHN HARWOOD

item.title: Philippines Tries to Temper Rodrigo Duterte’s Call for U.S. Withdrawal
item.media:description: Students demonstrated near the United States Embassy in Manila on Sunday against American intervention in the Philippines.
item.description: Military leaders said there were no plans for American troops to leave the south of the country, where they have been helping fight Islamist rebels.
item.dc:creator: FELIPE VILLAMOR
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Wukan, a Chinese Village, Erupts in Unrest Over Activists’ Arrests
item.media:description: Lin Zuluan, a leader in Wukan, was sentenced recently to three years in prison on corruption charges. Residents have held daily protests to call for his release.
item.description: The police responded with rubber bullets and tear gas, bloodying several people, according to interviews with villagers and images posted online.
item.dc:creator: JAVIER C. HERNÁNDEZ

item.title: Israel Denies Claims That Syria Shot Down Warplane and Drone
item.media:description: Israeli forces during a training exercise in the Israeli-held part of the Golan Heights on Tuesday.
item.description: Two missiles were fired at aircraft that were targeting artillery positions in the Syrian Golan Heights, but neither came close, the Israeli military said.
item.dc:creator: ISABEL KERSHNER and ANNE BARNARD

item.title: Germany Arrests 3 Syrians on Suspicion of ISIS Ties
item.media:description: A man suspected of having ties to Islamic State militants was taken by police officers to a courthouse in Karlsruhe, Germany, on Tuesday.
item.media:credit: Uli Deck/DPA, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.description: The three were among the tide of migrants who arrived in Germany and may have had links to last year’s Paris attackers, the authorities said.
item.dc:creator: MELISSA EDDY
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis

item.title: Italy’s ‘Fertility Day’ Call to Make Babies Arouses Anger, Not Ardor
item.media:description: “The government encourages us to have babies and then the main welfare system in Italy is still the grandparents,” said Vittoria Iacovella, a journalist and mother of two girls.
item.media:credit: Nadia Shira Cohen for The New York Times
item.description: A government ad campaign aimed at tackling Italy’s low birthrate was swiftly abandoned after it was widely deemed offensive.
item.dc:creator: GAIA PIANIGIANI

item.title: Sinosphere: Theater’s Evolving Role in China and Taiwan
item.media:description: A scene from a production of “A Dream Like a Dream” by Stan Lai in Beijing. The play has audiences sitting on swivel chairs in the center of the stage.
item.description: Stan Lai, a celebrated Chinese-language playwright and director, discusses changes in the theater industry and how his Buddhist beliefs influence his writing.
item.dc:creator: AMY QIN

item.title: U.S. and South Korea to Seek Strong Punishment Over North’s Nuclear Test
item.media:description: An American bomber, center, flying over Osan Air Base in South Korea.
item.description: They vowed to push for a resolution at the United Nations Security Council that includes new sanctions and the removal of existing loopholes.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Trapped in Homs, Architect Imagines a New Future for Syrian Cities
item.media:description: A sketch by Marwa al-Sabouni of possible future housing that echoes traditional architecture.
item.description: In a book and TED talk, Marwa al-Sabouni calls for a return to traditional styles, saying that recent construction has only fueled sectarian tensions.
item.dc:creator: STEPHEN HEYMAN

item.title: What in the World: Immortalized on the Streets of St. Petersburg: Kim Jong-il and Mannerheim
item.media:credit: Illustration by Leif Parsons; Photo by Andrey Kuzmin/shutterstock
item.description: To the bafflement and irritation of many people in St. Petersburg, Russia, their city has recently honored three people they would hardly call heroic or beloved.
item.dc:creator: LINCOLN PIGMAN

item.title: What in the World: Fear Descends Over Australia as Magpie Swooping Season Begins
item.media:credit: Illustration by Leif Parsons; photos by Fir0002/Flagstaffoto, Steve Carroll/shutterstock
item.description: It’s swooping season for the native magpie in Australia, and the birds are dive bombing and pecking at anything they deem a threat, especially humans.
item.dc:creator: SERENA SOLOMON

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Guatemala’s Fragile Progress
item.media:description: Protesting in June in Guatemala City against corruption involving the former president Otto Pérez Molina.
item.description: Victories against pervasive organized crime could be undone without continued U.S. and United Nations support.
item.dc:creator: ANITA ISAACS
item.category: International Commission Against Impunity in Guatemala (CICIG)

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Mohammad Javad Zarif: Let Us Rid the World of Wahhabism
item.description: The Saudis have spent billions exporting this extremist perversion of theology. It must stop.
item.dc:creator: MOHAMMAD JAVAD ZARIF

item.title: Editorial: How Bolivia Fights the Drug Scourge
item.media:description: Bolivia’s president, Evo Morales, in April after a special United Nations session on world drug problems.
item.description: Bolivia’s drug strategy is showing more promise than Washington’s forced-eradication model.
item.dc:creator: THE EDITORIAL BOARD
item.category: United Nations Office on Drugs and Crime

item.title: Turkish Dam Project Threatens to Submerge Thousands of Years of History
item.media:description: The Turkish town of Hasankeyf will be submerged under 200 feet of water after a hydroelectric dam now under construction is completed.
item.media:credit: Samuel Aranda for The New York Times
item.description: A contentious dam project that dates to the 1950s is more than 80 percent complete, and the filling of a reservoir will swamp much of the town of Hasankeyf.
item.dc:creator: TIM ARANGO

item.title: Devanampattinam Journal: Mortal to Divine and Back: India’s Transgender Goddesses
item.description: During the 10-day Hindu festival Mayana Kollai, the troubles of transgender women are distant as they transform into the deities they worship and are revered by villagers.
item.dc:creator: Photographs by CANDACE FEIT

item.title: Notebook: How Many Guns Did the U.S. Lose Track of in Iraq and Afghanistan? Hundreds of Thousands.
item.media:description: Iraqi soldiers after receiving new rifles from U.S. forces in Baghdad in May 2007.
item.description: A new study shows how the American military failed at the soldier’s most basic responsibility: keeping track of firearms.
item.dc:creator: C. J. CHIVERS
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: How Russia Often Benefits When Julian Assange Reveals the West’s Secrets
item.media:description: Julian Assange looking out from the Ecuadorean Embassy in London in February. Having lived there for four years, he is increasingly isolated.
item.description: American officials say Mr. Assange and WikiLeaks probably have no direct ties to Russian intelligence services. But the agendas of WikiLeaks and the Kremlin have often dovetailed.
item.dc:creator: JO BECKER, STEVEN ERLANGER and ERIC SCHMITT
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
